item.title: How to install MongoDB
item.description:
In this page you’ll find instructions to install MongoDB on your computer.

1 Instructions for MacOS users

You’ll need to use commands in the Terminal to install MongoDB.

1.1 Prerequisites

  • Install XCode. You’ll find it for free in the Mac App Store.

  • Install Homebrew. Command-line utility that let’s you install several software. Type the following command in the Terminal:

/bin/bash -c "$(curl -fsSL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Homebrew/install/master/install.sh)"

1.2 Installation

You can watch the following video that details how to install MongoDB, and launch the server and the client.

The commands used in the video are detailed below.

  • Tap the official MongoDB Homebrew tap with the following command:
brew tap mongodb/brew
  • Type the following command to install MongoDB:
brew install mongodb-community@4.4

1.3 Launch the MongoDB server

Type the following command:

brew services start mongodb-community@4.4

1.4 Launch the MongoDB client

Type the following command:

mongo

The terminal should display a character > (cf. the video above).

In order to verify that your installation works correctly, first create a database called test with the following command:

use test

Next, create a document in the database (you’ll learn about documents in the lecture devoted to MongoDB) by typing the following command:

 db.test_collection.insert({"key": 1});

If you get the message: WriteResult({ “nInserted” : 1 }) your installation works well!

1.5 Quit the MongoDB client

Next to the symbol > type the following command:

quit()

1.6 Stop the MongoDB server

Type the following command in the Terminal:

brew services stop mongodb-community@4.4
